Ministerial Statement for the Interior) -by leave-In 1901 the Seat of Government Act, which established Canberra as the nation's capital, envisaged the city as the centre of Federal administration and the seat of Parliament. This in itself called for the early establishment of an administrative and cultural centre with the prospect of a more impressive one to come in line with the expected growth of Australia and the national economy. The idea of a National Capital crystallised in 1911 with the launching of an international competition for the design of the city. The successful design demanded development worthy of the Australian nation, which would compare favourably with other national capitals. The Canberra plan, despite initial difficulties, was accepted, of rapid development under the guidance of the Federal Capital Commission then followed, culminating with the opening of the interim Houses of Parliament in 1927. period of relative stagnation created by, first, severe economic, and then wartime, conditions. Dissatisfaction with the rate of progress towards the fulfilment of the capital led to the setting up of a Senate Select Committee in 1954 to inquire into the development of Canberra. The report of the Senate Committee stressed the need for unifying the main activities involved in the development of the national capital and recommended that these activities be the responsibility of a separate commission with statutory powers. The Government of the day acted on this advice and accordingly the National Capital Development Commission was set up by Act of Parliament in 1957. This Parliament has, of course, always taken a direct interest in the growth of Canberra. The Commission, through its annual and special development reports, has kept the Parliament closely in touch with all aspects of the development of this city. Population growth has been particularly rapid in recent years. The plan for Canberra, prepared some fifty years ago, envisaged a city of 25,000 people with space for an ultimate 75,000 population.

I suggest that the Commonwealth take full responsibility, by making additional grants to the States, for the housing of the people it brings into the country. At the same time, we must ensure that housing for those already living in Australia keeps pace with any immigrant housing scheme. That is the figure given to me by the Minister for Immigration in answer to a question on 3rd September. But included in this figure are some 50,000 children. It could be said, therefore, that in round figures we have 200,000 immigrants qualified for naturalisation who have not taken the opportunity to become naturalised. We could well ponder on the solution to this problem. I have a list of the countries of origin of the immigrants who have not become naturalised. It shows that included in the 200,000 are more than 29,000 Dutch people, 25,000 Germans, 29,000 Greeks, 87,000 Italians, 13,000 Polish and 15,000 Yugoslavs. These people are apparently qualified in every way to be citizens but have not taken advantage of the opportunity to become naturalised. As politicians, problem, because these people are not taken into account, for instance, in the assessment of electors when electoral boun? daries are fixed. This is an important aspect of the problem and, of course, I do not wish to canvass it now. The system of fixing wages and of settling disputes is, to say the least -to place the most charitable interpretation on it-antiquate d in the extreme. As I said before the sitting was suspended, we have at present a system which is not one of arbitration at all. The word " arbitration " should be excised from the Act. The essence of arbitration is for equal parties with equal rights and status voluntarily to forgo the normal processes of litigation and submit their common issues in dispute to the arbitrament of an umpire duly appointed by them and whose awards they are prepared to accept. To put the matter in a nutshell, arbitrators do not impose sanctions. Yet sanctions are the very lifeblood of today's so-called system of arbitration. Before the suspension of the sitting 1 was referring to the types of jurists who are appointed to the arbitration court. I have a very great respect for the judiciary. Having had legal training I understand the requirements of the judiciary in the normal courts but when you are dealing with matters relating to wages, costs and profits you are in an entirely different sphere from that of deciding proprietary rights, of awarding damages for actionable wrongs, of determining breaches of the peace and of enforcing statutory and common law obligations upon individuals. I think the germ of the correct idea was incorporated in 1947 in the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act by the Chifley Government, which referred to the need for a special committee. Section 81AA. enacted in 1947 read(1.) For the purposes of this Act there shall be an Office of Economic and Industrial Research. (2.) The functions of the Office shall be(a) to collect and compile, in accordance with the directions of the Chief Judge, information which may be of assistance to the Court and to Conciliation Commissioners in the exercise of their powers and functions under this Act; (b) to keep information so collected and compiled up to date; and (c) to carry out research in respect of such matters as the Chief Judge directs. The point is this: Judges are not omniscient. In the complexities of modern society it is utterly impossible for judges, notwithstanding the breadth of their experience on the industrial commission, to adjudicate on the complexity and diversity of the problems associated with a modern, expanding and extremely diverse industrialised society. I think-thi s is only my opinion-that there is a strong case for special tribunals to consider special industries. That may be a solution to the problems of the automotive manufacturing industry. I cite as examples of the operation of such tribunals the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority and the Coal Industry Tribunal. In those cases special tribunals with special functions deal with the special problems of highly specialised industry. It is impossible today for judges to be economists and more and more the work that is being referred to them is work of an economic nature. In every branch of law there is a tendency for some pre-trial assessment and definition of the issues with a view to streamlining procedures. Today the average working man is frustrated and disappointed. He realises that unfortunately a majority of employers are prepared to take advantage of the delays and procrastinations associated with formal proof in a formal court that has evolved a most complex and unnecessary system of industrial jurisprudence.

I would say that the portrayal of Australia over a considerable period of time is now reaping a commensurate reward. Over the years, there have been from time to time various criticisms of Australian publicity abroad, according to the outlook and reaction of each particular critic. Australians who have been abroad, and people from other countries who come here, say that, perhaps too great an emphasis is placed on the illustration of our beaches, or too much attention is focussed on our outback, and too much, representation is made of our cities. But I feel that the very varied types of portrayal which have been given by the Department of Immigration and the Bureau of News and Information have built up overall what the advertising people call an image. In this case, it is a very favorable image of Australia, because we have now coming to Australia a record number of immigrants, despite the buoyant economic conditions of Europe, which have been referrred to by the honourable member for Hume in pointing out that immigration is running at a record level. It may be relevant at this point to say once again that the immigration target for 1964-65 has been established at 127,000 settlers, of whom 55,000 will be assisted migrants from Britain; 20,000 will be assisted migrants from other sources; and 52,000 will be unassisted settlers from all countries. The target of 55,000 assisted British migrants is the biggest target ever attempted in this country. I must say in connection with that matter that the target for British assisted migrants was established at this time last year at 45,000. Therefore, our target for this year provides for an additional 10,000 migrants. In the light of the growing demand for workers of all kind, and particularly because of the urgent need for certain categories of skilled workers, the programme was reviewed early in 1964 and the target for British assisted migrants for the financial year just completed was increased to 55,000. The actual arrivals for the financial year under that scheme were 54,630 Therefore, it can be understood why we approach with considerable con-fidence a target of 55,000 assisted migrants from the United Kingdom that has been set for this current financial year. We have provided also for a greater degree of flexibility-and I referred earlier in my speech to the flexibility that the Department needs in order to meet changing circumstances-so that by 31st December some 32,600 persons of the target of. 55,000 British assisted migrants will either, already be in Australia or on their way here. The article continuesIt says that Queensland and Western Australia are given fairly high marks on a score card based on financial stability and financial responsibility. On page 102 of the Fund Report for 1964 there is a table of the value of world gold production, gravely disturbing in its implications. It illustrates the Fund on the specific measures which it proposes dramatic decline in gold production in almost every country of the world since 1940. If we leave South African production out of the table, we find that Ihe value of free world production of gold has slumped from US. 772 million dollars in 1940 to US. 399 million dollars in 1963. Some may take comfort from the fact that the total value of free world production has moved from 1,264 million dollars in 1940 to 1,360 million dollars in 1963. An increase of this dimension in the production value of any commodity would be regarded as modest enough over an interval of 23 years, but detailed examination reveals that, with the notable exception of South Africa, whose value of production increased spectacularly over that period from 492 million dollars to 961 million dollars, of the remaining ten major producing countries listed, only one, Ghana, has shown an increase, and this only a marginal movement from 31 million dollars lo 32 million dollars. The combined value of all the others has shown a sharp decrease. Of the countries not listed individually but grouped under the heading " Other", the value of production has declined from 157 million dollars to 65 million dollars. We would have been discussing this question of international liquidity much earlier if gold reserves had not been propped up by South African production, which has more than doubled in value over the past ten years. But even in relation to that source of supply, the Fund Report has a sombre comment. It says on page 103 that 'South African production will have nearly reached its peak in 1964 or 1965. Thereafter it may level off for a few years, and subsequently decline.' It must be assumed from their reports that neither the Fund nor the Group of Ten contemplate any change in the price of gold. It remains to be seen how long this commodity can be held at a price fixed 30 years ago. It js against nature to hold it there unchanged indefinitely, regardless of general cost and price movements, and for my own part, I think we merely increase the difficulties of adjustment, the longer an adjustment is delayed. However whatever views we may hold on that aspect, we clearly need a comprehensive and up-to-date study by the Fund of the causes of the decline in gold production in so many countries, and an examination of methods whereby the supply of a metal fundamental to the liquidity of the International Monetary System can be substantially augmented. I would hope that by the time of our next meeting, such studies would not only have been put in hand, but their results made available to us early enough for a more searching discussion then."
